Article Title: Oracle founder Larry Ellison tells the biggest problem with AI models from Google, OpenAI, Meta, and other big tech companies
Article Text:
Oracle's Larry Ellison believes AI's next frontier is private enterprise data, not just public internet. He argues current models are commoditized and true value lies in securely accessing and reasoning over sensitive company information. Oracle is investing heavily, leveraging its vast database presence to become the enterprise AI backbone, facing competition from cloud rivals.

Oracle bets big on becoming the enterprise AI backbone

The race for private data access heats up





Oracle founder and CTO Larry Ellison has identified what he calls the critical limitation holding back AI models from Gemini to ChatGPT: they're all trained on the same publicly available internet data, making them increasingly commoditized with little real differentiation between them.Speaking during Oracle's fiscal Q2 2026 earnings call in December, Ellison argued that while training foundational models on public data has created "the largest and fastest-growing business in human history," the real value lies ahead in a second phase: enabling these models to securely reason over private enterprise data without compromising security."For these models to reach their peak value, you need to train them not just on publicly available data, but make privately owned data available for those models as well," Ellison said. He estimates this next phase will prove "even larger and more valuable" than the current GPU and data center boom.Oracle is positioning itself as uniquely equipped for this shift. The company points out that most of the world's high-value private data already lives in Oracle databases. Its AI Data Platform uses techniques like Retrieval-Augmented Generation to let any major AI model query private data in real-time while maintaining security.The company is backing this vision with aggressive spending, projecting roughly $50 billion in capital expenditures for the full year, up from $35 billion estimated in September. At Oracle AI World in October, the company announced partnerships including a 50,000-GPU AI supercluster with AMD MI450 chips launching in Q3 2026, and the OCI Zettascale10 supercomputer connecting hundreds of thousands of NVIDIA GPUs.Ellison's thesis faces challenges from multiple angles. Synthetic data generation could reduce dependence on exclusive proprietary data sets; real-time user interaction data from consumer apps could turn out to be more valuable than static enterprise records. At the same time, rivals like Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud are racing to develop comparable enterprise AI capabilities, though Oracle argues its established grip on enterprise databases gives it a strategic advantage. By late 2025, the company's cloud backlog had topped $500 billion, driven mostly by demand for AI.
Article Summary: Oracle's Larry Ellison believes AI's next frontier is private enterprise data. He argues current models are commoditized and true value lies in securely accessing and reasoning over sensitive company information. Oracle is investing heavily, leveraging its vast database presence to become the enterprise AI backbone.

The platform also includes large reasoning models, simulation tools to test rare or unusual driving situations, and open datasets that can be used for training and validation.Talking about Alpamayo, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said in a statement that ‚ÄúThe ChatGPT moment for physical AI is here ‚Äì when machines begin to understand, reason, and act in the real world‚Äù.‚ÄúIt's trained end-to-end. He said that his initial ability to launch Facebook wasn‚Äôt because he dropped out of college. According to Zuckerberg, it was due to the personal connections he made while he was still in school.Who you spend time with in college, Zuckerberg said, is ‚Äúthe most important decision‚Äù any student can make in college. He advised college students that choosing their social circle is the most pivotal decision, as people tend to emulate those around them. ‚ÄúYou become the people you surround yourself with,‚Äù he said in the podcast.‚ÄúI think probably people are too, in general, objective focused, and maybe not focused enough on the connections and the people who they‚Äôre basically building relationships [with]. ‚Äù Meta CEO Zuckerberg is said to have met his Facebook co-founders ‚Å†‚Äî Eduardo Saverin, Dustin Moskovitz, Chris Hughes and Andrew McCollum ‚Å†‚Äî while the five were students at Harvard University.While the group split up in a not-so-happy manner, Zuckerberg said on the podcast that he tries to prioritize relationships over objectives. Zoho senior engineer ships three-week projects in one day





Zoho founder and Chief Scientist Sridhar Vembu has revealed that one of his engineers recently built a sophisticated assembly and machine code security tool alone in just one month‚Äîwork that would typically require a team of three to four developers an entire year. The breakthrough, Vembu disclosed on X, came after the engineer discovered Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.5 model, which he called a "game changer" that finally convinced him AI-generated code was worth using."I did not know he was building it. Vembu shared that one of the company's most productive engineers‚Äîa veteran with two decades of experience handling performance-critical UI work‚Äîis now completing in a single day what previously took three weeks. "AI needed him to provide the structure, it fleshed out the details and that required him to draw on his experience," Vembu explained.The Indian SaaS giant has rolled out AI coding tools company-wide but with strict guardrails. Engineers must review and approve all AI-generated code and take full responsibility for it, Vembu emphasized. Zoho doesn't mandate AI usage, instead leaving implementation decisions to experienced developers who can assess when the technology adds value.Even junior developers are seeing breakthroughs. Vembu noted that a less experienced team member built an internal tool with AI assistance that's now being used across multiple teams‚Äîwork that wouldn't have been possible without the technology. Article Title: Nvidia announces Vera Rubin AI chip, claims it is 5X more powerful than Blackwell
Article Text:
What is the Vera Rubin AI platform

Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

Lower cost and faster AI processing

Elon Musk on Nvidia‚Äôs Rubin AI chip





Nvidia has unveiled its next-generation AI computing platform, called Vera Rubin, at the ongoing Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2026 in Las Vegas. The announcement was made by Nvidia founder and CEO Jensen Huang, who said the new platform is now in full production. Rubin is designed to support large-scale artificial intelligence workloads and is aimed at data centres, cloud providers and enterprises building advanced AI systems. Nvidia said the platform is built to lower the cost of AI computing and support faster training and deployment of AI models. Rubin succeeds Nvidia‚Äôs Blackwell architecture and is part of the company‚Äôs broader push to expand AI use across industries.Vera Rubin is Nvidia‚Äôs first six-chip AI platform developed using an ‚Äúextreme codesign‚Äù approach, where multiple components are designed together. The platform includes Rubin GPUs, Vera CPUs, NVLink 6 networking, Spectrum-X Ethernet Photonics, ConnectX-9 networking cards and BlueField-4 data processing units. Nvidia said this design helps reduce bottlenecks and improve performance for large AI workloads.The Rubin GPU delivers up to 50 petaflops of inference performance using NVFP4 precision. The Vera CPU is designed to handle data movement and AI agent processing tasks. Nvidia said the platform is built to support large-scale AI training and inference more efficiently.According to Nvidia, the Rubin platform can reduce the cost of generating AI tokens to about one-tenth of previous platforms. The company also introduced an AI-focused storage system called Inference Context Memory Storage, which is designed to improve long-context AI processing by increasing speed and efficiency.Nvidia said the Rubin platform will be used alongside its open AI models and software tools to support applications in areas such as autonomous driving, robotics, healthcare and climate research.The announcement was shared by an X user Sawyer Merritt who also shared a video of the chip maker‚Äôs next-generation Rubin chips. Responding to the post, Musk said ‚ÄúIt will take another 9 months or so before the hardware is operational at scale and the software works well‚Äù, highlighting deployment realities beyond raw power claims.
Article Summary: Vera Rubin is Nvidia‚Äôs first six-chip AI platform developed using an ‚Äúextreme codesign‚Äù approach, where multiple components are designed together. The Rubin platform can reduce the cost of generating AI tokens to about one-tenth of previous platforms.

Article Title: UAE‚Äôs cloud seeding secret: How salt, AI, drones are used to make it rain in desert
Article Text:
How Does It Rain in the Desert? The UAE‚Äôs Cloud-Seeding Secret Explained

Cloud seeding is not magic but meteorology, planes, salt and cloud chemistry

Why It Rains in the UAE: Planes, AI and the Science of Desert Rain

From Salt to Satellites: How the UAE Is Hacking the Sky to Make It Rain

Tech upgrades: Nano materials and AI assist for cloud seeding



Nano-materials: New seed agents that can be up to three times more effective than traditional salt flares.

New seed agents that can be up to three times more effective than traditional salt flares. AI-guided targeting: Artificial intelligence helps meteorologists analyse massive weather datasets and choose optimal seeding targets in real time, meaning every flight has the best shot at inducing rain.

Ground-based generators: In mountainous areas, ground stations release seeding materials into rising winds that carry them up into clouds.

Is cloud seeding working? What the data says



AI, Aircraft and Salt Crystals: How the UAE Is Boosting Rainfall

Cloud seeding myths, misunderstandings and real weather



How cloud seeding works

Bottom line







Even if you have never been to a desert, you would have seen it on screens, how rain bursts despite arid desert sun but in the UAE, rain does not just happen by chance. Behind the scenes, scientists are actively nudging clouds to drop more water, using aircraft, salt crystals, artificial intelligence and some of the world‚Äôs most advanced weather-tech. Yes, there is a real-world rain machine in one of the planet‚Äôs driest regions.Welcome to the UAE‚Äôs cloud-seeding programme, a long-running national effort to enhance rainfall in a place that normally gets less than 100 mm of rain a year.The concept is simpler than it sounds. The UAE does not create rain from thin air, it enhances rain that might already be there. Scientists constantly scan the skies using sophisticated weather radars and 26 live camera feeds to spot developing cumulus clouds with potential.When conditions look right, they are ready to act. From meteorological radar data to real-time cloud analysis, researchers identify the best moments and places to intervene, no crystal balls required.When suitable clouds form, specially equipped aircraft take to the skies. Pilots fly into the updrafts, rising currents of air within convective clouds and deploy seeding agents like microscopic salt crystals mixed with magnesium, sodium chloride and potassium chloride.These tiny particles act as condensation nuclei, meaning that they attract and cluster water droplets within the cloud. As droplets grow larger and heavier, gravity finally pulls them down as rainfall instead of letting them evaporate in the dry desert air.In 2025 alone, the UAE reported 172 cloud-seeding flights, aiming to boost rain, not create weather from nothing.Think cloud seeding is stuck in the last century? The truth is that the UAE has invested in cutting-edge innovations -Together, these upgrades are pushing cloud-seeding into a more efficient ‚Äúrain-tech‚Äù arena rather than a simple aerial stunt.Studies and operational data suggest that cloud seeding can increase rainfall by roughly 10% to 25% under the right conditions and is significant when every extra drop counts. Some research even links cloud-seeded storms to larger volumes of water reaching the ground, with gains measured in hundreds of millions of cubic metres of usable water annually, a real lifeline in a region where water security is a top priority.Still, experts caution that cloud seeding is not a perfect rainmaker as it cannot produce rain unless clouds already have moisture and results can vary depending on atmospheric conditions. The UAE‚Äôs water challenges are real. Rapid urban growth and limited natural freshwater mean the country relies heavily on desalination plants, recycled water and cloud seeding to meet its needs.Cloud seeding is far more cost-effective than desalination for extra water as one flight costs around US $8,000 per hour, a bargain when compared to the energy and infrastructure required to turn seawater into drinking water. That is why the UAE has invested millions of dollars into research and technology, including local manufacturing of seed materials and international scientific partnerships.Despite its gains, cloud seeding sometimes gets blamed for extreme weather like the surprising flooding seen in parts of the Emirates. However, meteorologists are clear that cloud seeding cannot create storms out of nothing. Heavy rains during major weather events are natural phenomena that cloud seeding can neither trigger nor control.In social media discussions, some critics call cloud seeding ‚Äúscam technology‚Äù or blame it for unexpected rainfall but even sceptics acknowledge that the programme generally only enhances rain when clouds already exist. Cloud seeding in the UAE is not about controlling nature, it is about coaxing nature to give a little extra.As climate change increases weather unpredictability and water scarcity pressures mount, experts see rain enhancement as one valuable tool among many. Whether it is planes, drones, nano-powder or AI pilots, the UAE‚Äôs cloud-seeding programme is a fascinating blend of technology, meteorology and environmental strategy. It is a uniquely desert-born experiment in making the sky work for people.The UAE‚Äôs effort to ‚Äúmake it rain‚Äù is not science fiction, it is a real, high-tech programme combining radar, planes, salts, nano-materials and AI to enhance rainfall in one of the driest climates on Earth. While it has limitations, cloud seeding represents a creative response to water scarcity, one that other water-stressed regions are watching closely.

Scientists constantly scan the skies using sophisticated weather radars and 26 live camera feeds to spot developing cumulus clouds with potential. Pilots fly into the updrafts, rising currents of air within convective clouds and deploy seeding agents like microscopic salt crystals.

Article Title: Microsoft: Tech Layoffs: Layoffs at Microsoft, Meta, Google, Twitter: What is 'career cushioning' and why it's important
Article Text:
As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning'.

Q: What is career cushioning?

Q: Why is career cushioning important?

Q: How can I start career cushioning?

Q: What are some examples of career cushioning?

Q: Is career cushioning only for people in certain industries?

Q: How often should I review and update my career cushioning efforts?

Q: How do I know if my career cushioning efforts are working?

Q: How much time should I be dedicating to career cushioning?

NEW DELHI: Microsoft Corp is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, with some roles expected to be eliminated in the human resources and engineering divisions, according to media reports on Tuesday.This move follows similar job cuts announced by other tech companies, such as Amazon, Meta Platforms , Twitter, Google , Salesforce and a host of other corporations.These job cuts are being attributed to slowing demand and a worsening global economic outlook. The move by Microsoft indicates that the tech sector may continue to shed jobs in the coming months.As job cuts continue to rise in tech and various other industries, some employees are choosing to proactively seek out new job opportunities while still employed. This strategy, referred to as " career cushioning ". Here is all you need to know on 'career cushioning'A: Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable and resilient to job loss or industry changes. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.A: Career cushioning can help provide a sense of security and confidence in uncertain job markets and can also open up new opportunities for career advancement. It can also help you be better prepared if you do lose your job, making it easier to find new employment.A: There are several ways to begin career cushioning, such as:Building a diverse skill set through continuing education or volunteer workNetworking with professionals in your industry and other industriesBuilding a personal brand through social media and professional online presenceSaving money for unexpected career changes or job loss.A: Some examples of career cushioning include:-A software developer taking on freelance web design projects to gain experience in user interface design.-A marketing professional starting a blog to gain experience in content creation.-A sales representative taking on additional responsibilities in product development to gain experience in product management.A: No, career cushioning is applicable for people in any industry. It's about being proactive in preparing for potential changes in your career, regardless of the industry you're in.A: It's a good idea to review your career cushioning efforts regularly, perhaps once or twice a year. This will allow you to assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plans. Additionally, keeping an eye on the job market and industry trends can help you anticipate and prepare for any potential changes in your field.A: You can gauge the effectiveness of your career cushioning efforts by monitoring your progress in gaining new skills and experiences, as well as the feedback you receive from your professional network and potential employers. Additionally, you may find that you are better able to adapt to changes in your industry, or that you have more opportunities available to you.A: The amount of time you should dedicate to career cushioning will depend on your individual goals and circumstances, however it's important to balance the time you spend career cushioning with your other responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is to spend some time each week or month working on career cushioning activities, but not to the point that it negatively impacts other areas of your life.
Article Summary: As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning' Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.

Article Title: SanDisk Optimus is the new name for WD Black and Blue Drives
Article Text:
SanDisk is retiring its popular WD Black and WD Blue SSD branding for gaming and performance drives, introducing the 'Optimus' name at CES 2026. The new lineup features three tiers: Optimus for creators, Optimus GX for gamers, and Optimus GX Pro for high-end professionals.





SanDisk is moving on from Western Digital's iconic color-coded branding. The storage giant announced at CES 2026 that its gaming and performance SSDs will now carry the Optimus name, retiring the well-known WD Black and WD Blue labels that enthusiasts have trusted for years.The rebrand splits into three tiers. The base Optimus line targets content creators looking for solid performance without breaking the bank‚Äîessentially the old WD Blue drives like the SN5100.The Optimus GX are gaming-focused drives prioritizing quick load times and promising not to drain your system's power, taking over from WD Black models like the SN7100. The top-shelf Optimus GX Pro is where SanDisk parks its fastest hardware, built for developers and pros running AI workstations or souped-up gaming rigs that demand every ounce of performance. Think of it as the replacement for premium WD Black drives like the SN8100.SanDisk says the new naming scheme makes it easier to identify which drive fits your needs, though some might argue the old color system was pretty straightforward. The company is also introducing fresh packaging with bold red, black, and white designs that look nothing like the previous generation.The Optimus name has roots in SanDisk's history‚Äîit originally came from SMART Storage Systems, which SanDisk acquired back in 2013.The last Optimus-branded drive launched in 2014 before the line went dormant, making this a comeback story of sorts.Products with the new branding will start appearing on shelves worldwide during the first half of 2026. Older WD-branded drives will stick around while supplies last, though don't expect major clearance sales given how unpredictable SSD pricing tends to be. The transition officially kicked off with Sunday's announcement at CES.

Article Title: Did Starmer impose a curfew in the UK? No, it's just a fake TikTok video
Article Text:
Keir Starmer

The 61-second video of UK PM Keir Starmer would be shocking, if it were true. "The UK is set to introduce a nationwide curfew, beginning at 11pm each night," he appears to say on one of thousands of TikTok videos of him posted in last six months. "Under the new rule, no one will be permitted to leave their home after 11pm without official authorisation."Starmer never made any such policy or announcement. But thanks to AI, the PM in the short video sounded eerily like the real one. The fake video attracted over 430,000 views and inspired similar posts on X and Facebook. That video, and other similar ones, appears to have been taken down by the Chinese-owned social media company, which officially prohibits "fake authoritative sources or crisis events, or falsely shows public figures in certain contexts. "But the clip was just one of 6,042 such videos, most featuring Starmer, identified by NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, between May and Dec. In a report, it said the videos were posted by accounts with names of fake, British-sounding news organisations like "BBB UK News" and "Daily Britain News." Together, the accounts had more than 1 million followers when the report was issued. "It consistently emulates Starmer," said Eva Maitland, senior analyst for Russian influence at NewsGuard."It produces false or baseless claims that look bad for the Starmer govt, and they're kind of created to create a strong response from people so that they'll click on it."Maitland said the videos do not appear to be part of a coordinated effort by foreign adversaries like Russia or the PM's domestic political opponents to damage him in the eyes of voters. Rather, she said, they are likely being created by content producers whose primary goal is to make money by making videos that go viral.The widespread adoption of easy-to-use AI video generation tools, like OpenAI's Sora, has dramatically increased the number of fake videos on TikTok and other social media platforms. The fake videos come at a particularly difficult time for the PM, who is already suffering from very low polling numbers. In one video, Starmer seems to announce new drivers licence laws that could strip many British people of their ability to drive legally in the country. Another video has Starmer's faked voice declaring that new rules will allow the authorities to access any British person's phone, along with its private data.In the immediate days after NewsGuard published its report on Dec 9, many of the videos were available on TikTok. By Dec 19, most appeared to have been removed from the platform. Howard said the use of AI in politics is increasing rapidly. "We know it's internationally pervasive now," he said. "Four of every five elections around the world now have AI-generated political junk that is unattributed and clearly misleading. "
Article Summary: Thousands of fake videos of UK PM Keir Starmer have been posted on TikTok. The videos were created by accounts with fake, British-sounding news organisations. NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, identified 6,042 such videos between May and Dec.

Northern skies do not always announce themselves. Most nights pass quietly, even when something distant is shifting above the planet. This week is slightly different. A pulse of solar activity is moving through Earth‚Äôs magnetic field, and that change may be just enough to push the northern lights into view across parts of the United States. It is not guaranteed, and it will not look the same everywhere. Some people may see soft colour low on the horizon, others nothing at all. Still, for a short window in early January, the odds tilt a little. Space weather forecasters are watching closely, and so are sky watchers, hoping the darkness offers something unexpected rather than empty for once during the coldest stretch of winter nights.The strongest chances sit far north, as they usually do. Alaska remains the most reliable place, almost separate from the rest of the map when it comes to aurora watching. Parts of:These areas lie closer to where Earth‚Äôs magnetic field funnels charged particles into the atmosphere. NOAA forecasts suggest activity could peak overnight between January 8 and January 9, though timing often slips by hours. In these states, the lights may form brighter arcs or slow-moving curtains rather than faint smudges. Even then, nothing is promised. Auroras are known for appearing briefly and fading without warning.States a little below the usual aurora belt are not entirely out of luck. Minnesota, Michigan, and Maine often sit on the edge during moderate geomagnetic storms, and this week could be another of those moments.The display in these places is usually subtle. Colour may appear washed out, sometimes closer to grey than green. It often stays low in the northern sky, easy to mistake for a cloud or distant glow. Wyoming, Vermont, New Hampshire, and parts of New York fall into a similar category. For viewers there, seeing the aurora often depends on patience and expectations. Many who do catch it only realise later when photos reveal more than the eye noticed at the time.The trigger comes from the Sun, though not in a dramatic, cinematic way. A coronal mass ejection has sent a stream of charged particles outward, interacting with a co rotating interaction region already moving through space. Together, they disturb Earth‚Äôs magnetic field just enough to produce a G1-level geomagnetic storm. That rating is considered minor, but minor does not mean invisible. It simply means effects are more local and less intense. Space weather remains difficult to predict with precision. Solar wind speed, density, and direction can all shift suddenly. Forecasts improve as the storm arrives, but uncertainty never fully disappears.Even the strongest aurora means little under thick cloud. Cloud cover remains the biggest reason people miss these events, regardless of solar activity. Clear skies matter more than most other factors. Light pollution is the next obstacle. Urban lighting can wash out faint auroras entirely, especially in southern locations. Rural areas, coastal stretches, and dark sky parks offer better odds. Many experienced observers suggest letting your eyes adjust and avoiding phone screens for a while. Cameras often see more than humans do, especially in low light modes. Sometimes the night still looks empty. Sometimes it does not. That uncertainty is part of the pull.
Article Summary: The strongest chances sit far north, as they usually do. Alaska remains the most reliable place, almost separate from the rest of the map when it comes to aurora watching. Minnesota, Michigan, and Maine often sit on the edge during moderate geomagnetic storms, and this week could be another of those moments.

Article Title: Ask Dhirendra: 'How do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?'
Article Text:
The problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save. (AI image)

‚ÄúHow do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?‚Äù

What can you save today without breaking your life? How can you make that number grow every year?

Where does a typical salary go?

Some expenses are non-negotiable (rent, basic food, fees).

Some are negotiable but important (a modest phone, occasional eating out).

Some are pure leakage (unused subscriptions, impulsive orders, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even remember what this was‚Äù).

From spare change to serious money

Step up your SIP before you step up your lifestyle

First, add up your genuine essentials: rent/EMI, groceries, utilities, fees, basic transport.

Next, be realistic and add a modest amount for discretionary spending that you know you‚Äôll do anyway ‚Äì because you are human, not a robot.

See what is left. From that leftover, commit to a percentage ‚Äì even 10% of your take-home income ‚Äì as a non-negotiable saving and investing amount. Set up automatic transfers and SIPs for that right after your salary date.

If you have any queries for Dhirendra Kumar you can drop us an email at: toi.business@timesinternet.in

(Dhirendra Kumar is Founder and CEO of Value Research)

This is one of those questions that sounds technical, but is actually very emotional.On paper, it‚Äôs simple: income comes in, expenses go out, and whatever is left is ‚Äúsavings. In real life, income comes in, rent, EMIs, school fees, petrol, Swiggy, Zomato, sale on Myntra, birthday gifts, one sudden expense‚Ä¶ and at the end of the month, you look at your balance and say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start investing from next month. Pakka.‚ÄùNext month looks surprisingly similar.So let‚Äôs start with an honest admission: for most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough.At Value Research, whenever we look at this, we don‚Äôt begin with a number like ‚Äúyou must save 30%‚Äù. We start with a different idea: savings are not what is left after spending. Savings are what you decide first; spending adjusts after that if you flip this order, the maths ‚Äì and your behaviour ‚Äì changes completely.A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income to savings and investments. However, I also know that for many people today, 30% sounds like a bad joke. So instead of fighting over the ‚Äúideal‚Äù number, let‚Äôs work with two simpler questions:To answer the first question, you need to know where your money is actually going, not where you think it is going.For one or two months, track your expenses honestly ‚Äì not for Instagram, for yourself. You don‚Äôt need an app; even a simple notebook or spreadsheet works.Once you see your own pie chart, three things usually stand out:Your first ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù might simply be plugging two or three leaks. Even if that frees up only ‚Çπ2,000‚Äì‚Çπ3,000 a month, that is your starting SIP.Now let‚Äôs look at how ‚Äúsmall‚Äù that really is.When we run these numbers at Value Research in our retirement and goal calculators, the results are always the same: the gap between zero and small is far bigger than the gap between small and perfect.But what if your income truly is at the survival stage? There are people for whom even ‚Çπ2,000 is a luxury some months. If that‚Äôs your reality, you have two parallel jobs. One is to create a tiny habit ‚Äì even ‚Çπ500 or ‚Çπ1,000 a month into a recurring deposit or a conservative fund. The absolute amount is less important than the mental switch from ‚ÄúI‚Äôll save if anything is left‚Äù to ‚ÄúI will save something, and then I will live on the rest. ‚ÄùThe second job is to make sure that as your income grows, your lifestyle doesn‚Äôt expand at the same speed. This is where a lot of middle-class Indians quietly sabotage themselves. Every salary increase automatically becomes a better phone, nicer meals out, upgraded gadgets, and bigger car loans. The percentage saved stays the same, or sometimes even falls.A very powerful habit ‚Äì one we often build into plans at Value Research ‚Äì is the ‚Äústep-up‚Äù. Each year, when your salary goes up, you increase your SIPs and savings before you upgrade anything else.In many examples we‚Äôve run, the step-up strategy leads to a dramatically higher corpus at the end, without you ever feeling an acute ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù in any single year. You just avoid letting every pay hike leak out into lifestyle.Now, how do you decide your own number?Here‚Äôs a simple approach:If that number feels tight, start a little lower and promise yourself one thing: every time your income goes up, your savings rate will go up faster than your spending.At Value Research, when we build long-term plans, we don‚Äôt assume people will suddenly start saving 40% from next month. We assume they will start somewhere realistic, and then we design step-ups. The rigour is in the process, not in some magical starting number.One last point. Many people postpone investing because they are embarrassed by how small their starting amount looks. Please don‚Äôt underestimate the psychological power of seeing a small, growing pile that you started and maintained. It changes how you think about yourself: from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt save‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am someone who always saves something.‚Äù That identity is worth more than one extra dinner out.So how much should you save and invest when your income feels just about enough? The honest answer is: start with whatever you can without lying to yourself, protect that amount like you protect your rent, and then make sure it rises every time your income increases. The ‚Äúright‚Äù number is not what a formula says; it‚Äôs the number you will actually stick to for the next 20 years.The perfect percentage can wait. The first rupee cannot.
Article Summary: Dhirendra Kumar: For most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough. A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income.

When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.

Every year, lakhs of pensioners across India must prove that they are still alive to continue receiving their pension. This verification, known as the Life Certificate or Digital Life Certificate (DLC), is a crucial and mandatory step in ensuring that pension payments are made only to eligible recipients, preventing fraud and misuse.Traditionally, this process involved visiting the bank or pension office in person, standing in long queues, and submitting a signed paper certificate. However, with the government‚Äôs focus on digitisation and technological advancement, this process has become much simpler, faster, and more convenient. Pensioners can now submit their certificates digitally from the comfort of their homes using Jeevan Pramaan, a secure, user-friendly, and Aadhaar-based platform.A Life Certificate is an official document that confirms a pensioner is alive. Without it, pension payments are automatically paused by the pension disbursing agency. This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries.The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric-enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.Introduced by the Government of India, it uses Aadhaar-based biometric authentication using either fingerprint or iris scan to verify a pensioner‚Äôs identity. Once verified, a digital certificate is automatically generated and shared with authorised pension disbursing agencies.This online process eliminates the need for physical verification, providing elderly pensioners with a simpler and more accessible way to maintain their pension benefits.According to PIB, The submission of the Life Certificate is mandatory for all pensioners who wish to continue receiving their pension without interruption. For the year 2025, the standard submission period is betweenTo make the process more comfortable for the elderly, the government allows pensioners aged 80 years and above to begin the submission process earlier, from 1 October 2025. This extended window gives senior citizens more time and flexibility to complete the procedure without facing last-minute difficulties.The Jeevan Pramaan process involves two main steps: registering the biometric device and generating the digital certificate.Before using the service, pensioners or operators must register their biometric device such as a fingerprint or iris scanner. During registration, the user provides their Aadhaar number and mobile number, after which an OTP (One-Time Password) is sent to their mobile. After entering the OTP, they must provide their name and email ID before scanning their fingerprint or iris.Once authentication is complete, the system confirms that device registration was successful, allowing the user to move to the next step.In this step, the pensioner enters personal details such as Aadhaar number, mobile number, name, PPO number, pension type, sanctioning authority, disbursing agency, and bank account details. The system also asks whether the pensioner has remarried or is re-employed.After entering all details, the pensioner scans their fingerprint or iris using the registered biometric device. Upon successful authentication, the Digital Life Certificate is generated, and an SMS acknowledgment with the Jeevan Pramaan Certificate ID is sent to the registered mobile number.This certificate is automatically stored in the Life Certificate Repository, accessible anytime to both pensioners and pension agencies.Once the Digital Life Certificate is created, it can be electronically delivered to the concerned Pension Disbursing Agency (PDA). PDAs can log in to the Jeevan Pramaan portal to view, verify, or download the certificate directly.Pensioners can also download a PDF copy of their certificate by visiting the Jeevan Pramaan website and entering their Pramaan ID or Aadhaar number. This ensures transparency and easy access for future reference.The government provides several options to submit the Life Certificate, allowing pensioners to choose the method that suits them best.Pensioners who prefer traditional methods can visit their bank branch or a Citizen Service Centre (CSC) to submit their Life Certificate physically. Trained staff at these centres assist pensioners in verifying their details and completing the process.For those unable to travel due to age or health issues, India Post Payments Bank (IPPB) offers a doorstep banking service. Pensioners can schedule an appointment, and an IPPB representative will visit their home to complete the submission using biometric authentication. This service is available for both IPPB and non-IPPB account holders.For pensioners comfortable with technology, the Jeevan Pramaan portal provides a completely online process. By visiting https://jeevanpramaan.gov.in, pensioners can submit their Digital Life Certificate using a computer, laptop, or smartphone equipped with a fingerprint or iris scanner.The system uses the Aadhaar platform to authenticate biometric details. Once verification is successful, a Digital Life Certificate is generated and stored in a secure online repository. Pension disbursing agencies can then directly access the certificate, removing the need for physical paperwork.The UMANG (Unified Mobile Application for New-age Governance) app offers another easy option. Pensioners can download the app from the Google Play Store, search for ‚ÄúJeevan Pramaan,‚Äù and select ‚ÄúGenerate Life Certificate.‚ÄùAfter entering the necessary details such as Aadhaar number, PPO number, and type of pension, pensioners must authenticate themselves using biometric verification. The app then generates a Digital Life Certificate (DLC), which is automatically shared with the pension disbursing authority.All pensioners who receive government, defence, or private sector pensions through authorised disbursing agencies are required to submit their Life Certificate every year. This includes:Failure to submit the certificate within the stipulated period may result in temporary suspension of pension payments until verification is completed.To ensure a smooth submission process, pensioners should keep certain details and documents ready. These include:Having these details ready helps to avoid delays or errors during authentication, whether submitting online or offline.Yes, an Aadhaar number or Virtual ID (VID) is mandatory to generate a Digital Life Certificate. The entire Jeevan Pramaan system is based on Aadhaar authentication, which ensures accuracy and prevents fraud. Pensioners must make sure their Aadhaar is linked with their mobile number and bank account before attempting to generate the certificate.The Digital Life Certificate is fully valid and legally recognised under the Information Technology Act. Pension disbursing authorities across India accept it as an official document, equivalent to the traditional paper-based life certificate.Its biometric verification system makes it secure and tamper-proof, reducing the chances of wrongful pension disbursal or misuse of pension funds.Before the introduction of Jeevan Pramaan, pensioners often faced difficulties in submitting their certificates, especially those with health problems or limited mobility. The digital system has removed these challenges, allowing pensioners to submit their verification anytime and anywhere.By integrating biometric technology and Aadhaar authentication, Jeevan Pramaan has streamlined pension management, improving efficiency for both pensioners and government departments. It also enhances transparency and ensures that genuine beneficiaries receive payments on time.

This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries. The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric- enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.

Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

Article Title: Inside Apple‚Äôs beginnings: Steve Jobs‚Äô childhood items and early products head to auction
Article Text:

A wide-ranging collection of Steve Jobs‚Äô childhood belongings and some of Apple‚Äôs earliest products has gone up for auction as the company approaches its 50th anniversary on April 1, 2026. The sale is being handled by RR Auction, which has opened bidding on 191 items spanning Jobs‚Äô early life and Apple‚Äôs formative period in the mid-1970s.Among the centrepieces of the auction is the first known cheque issued by Apple Computer, Inc. on March 16, 1976. Signed by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, the $500 cheque was made out to Howard Cantin, who designed the printed circuit board for the Apple-1 computer. The document predates Apple‚Äôs official incorporation and is described by the auction house as a foundational artefact from the company‚Äôs earliest days.Also drawing strong interest is the earliest known prototype motherboard for the Apple-1, alongside other rare hardware from Apple‚Äôs pre-Macintosh era. Early bidding has already pushed some items into the tens of thousands of dollars, with expectations that final prices could climb far higher.The auction also includes a functional Lisa-1 computer, a key transitional machine that preceded Apple‚Äôs Macintosh line, as well as a first-generation iPhone that was later jailbroken by teenage hacker George Hotz.Together, the items trace Apple‚Äôs evolution from a garage-based start-up to a consumer electronics giant.Adding a more personal dimension, the collection features items from Jobs‚Äô childhood and teenage years, provided to the auction house by his stepbrother, John Chovanec. These include bowties, Bob Dylan 8-track tapes, and the wooden desk from Jobs‚Äô bedroom at the Los Altos, California home later associated with the famed ‚ÄúApple garage‚Äù.Other personal effects include components from Jobs‚Äô own Apple-1 computer, hand-annotated car repair manuals, and a short handwritten note to his father on an early Apple business card.Rounding out the auction are original Apple marketing posters from the 1970s and 1980s, along with internal documents and ephemera from the company‚Äôs earliest phase. Together, the items offer a rare, material record of Apple‚Äôs origins and the personal world of its co-founder.Bidding for the collection is open until January 29, with interest expected to grow as the anniversary year approaches.
Article Summary: Collection of Steve Jobs‚Äô childhood belongings and some of Apple‚Äôs earliest products has gone up for auction as the company approaches its 50th anniversary on April 1, 2026. Article Title: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu after tech town hall on AI-generated code: 'I now have a much clearer understanding of...'
Article Text:

‚ÄòHuman intervention needed in complex codes‚Äô





Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu has shared insights from a code review of C++ generated by Anothropic‚Äôs LLM, saying that he was impressed but thinks that AI still have room for development. He also suggested that LLMs coding still need human intervention but there has been a significant improvement in such capabilities in the last two years.According to Vembu, the review went on for hours in the tech town hall and it provided him a clear understanding on how LLMs work.‚ÄúYesterday we had a tech town hall in Zoho where we did a code review of the C++ code generated by the Claude Opus 4.5 model. It went on for hours late evening,‚Äù Vembu said in a post on X (formerly Twitter).‚ÄúI now have a much clearer understanding of what these models do well: they are able to stitch together systems well, taking data from one system, reshape it and pass it to another system. There is often a lot of such "glue code" in these systems and that is not very complicated but it is very tedious,‚Äù he added.He also highlighted AI's strength in creating tedious ‚Äúglue code‚Äù for system integration but noted that its tendency toward verbose outputs and reliance on memorised open-source patterns.‚ÄúIn general, AI models have "memorized" all the open source too and they are able to recall patterns from them (with some possibility of hallucination). They are also able to stitch various open source pieces together well,‚Äù Vembu pointed out.Vembu also highlighted that human orchestration proved essential during their review as it ensured usable results. He said that while AI excels at stitching components but it struggles with complexity.‚ÄúOur senior engineer had guided ("orchestrated" is the right word) this process. When the AI was stuck he helped "unstuck" it. This was a very vital contribution and without his experienced guidance, the AI output would not be useful,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe examined several C++ files with thousands of lines of code in each, looking for what I consider complex code. Most of it was straightforward glue code and only a tiny part of it was complex,‚Äù Vembu noted.‚ÄúI suspect that the AI generated code tended to be needlessly verbose but I have to study it more to be sure. On the whole, I am both impressed and not super awed. I believe we can do better,‚Äù he concluded.

Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman recently shared what he sees as a key test for the next stage of artificial intelligence (AI). To me that's the modern Turing Test,‚Äù Mustafa Suleyman wrote in a post on microblogging platform X (formerly Twitter).Suleyman‚Äôs comments come as several technology leaders including OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff bet heavily on AI agents as the next major shift in enterprise software. Article Title: Nikon launches NIKKOR Z 24-105mm f/4-7.1 lens in India for Rs 49,995
Article Text:
Nikon has unveiled its new Z-mount 24-105mm f/4-7.1 lens in India, offering a versatile full-frame zoom at an affordable Rs 49,995. Weighing just 350 grams, it excels in close-up photography with impressive magnification. The lens features a quiet stepping motor for video and a customizable control ring. Compatible with Nikon's Hi-Res Zoom, it extends reach to 210mm.





Nikon has launched its latest Z-mount lens, the NIKKOR Z 24-105mm f/4-7.1, in India, bringing a versatile full-frame zoom option to its mirrorless lineup at an accessible price point of Rs 49,995.The new standard zoom covers everything from wide-angle landscapes at 24mm to medium-telephoto portraits and distant subjects at 105mm. Despite this flexibility, it weighs just 350 grams‚Äîlight enough to comfortably carry through extended shooting sessions without causing fatigue.Close-up photography is where the lens shows some real promise. It focuses as close as 0.2 meters at the wide end and 0.28 meters when zoomed in, with a maximum reproduction ratio of 0.5√ó between 70-105mm. That's enough magnification to capture flowers, food, and small details with pleasing background blur that isolates your subject.Video shooters get a stepping motor that delivers fast, quiet autofocus without the distracting whirring sounds that can ruin audio. The lens also includes a customizable control ring that can be assigned to adjust focus, aperture, exposure compensation, or ISO sensitivity‚Äîwhatever fits your shooting style.One of the highlights of this lens is its ability to work with Hi-Res Zoom on the following Nikon bodies: Z9, Z8, Z6III, Z5II, Zf, Z50II, and ZR. This has an effective range of 210mm, allowing for more flexibility when the photographer is not close enough to take a clear shot of the subject.Nikon has also included dust and drip resistance, although these are not touted as making the camera completely weather-tight. However, it is comforting to know that these are features in case the weather does not behave as expected.The NIKKOR Z 24-105mm f/4-7.1 will be available at Nikon outlets across India from mid-January 2026.

The lens features a quiet stepping motor for video and a customizable control ring. Compatible with Nikon's Hi-Res Zoom, it extends reach to 210mm.
